We were just hearing from John McWhorter, Manhattan Institute senior fellow in public policy, Callie Crossley, social and cultural commentator on the Boston television show ""Beat the Press,"" and Michael Meyers, executive director, New York Civil Rights Coalition.
And Michael, speaking of civil rights, there are voter identification requirements intended to eliminate fraud.
But apparently they can also reduce turnout among minorities.
A new study by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University shows that the turn out in 2004 was about four percent lower in states that required voters to sign their name or produce ID.
And for African-Americans it dropped by six percent in those areas.
So are these anti-fraud laws or are these the modern day equivalent of the poll tax?
I will not call them the modern day equivalent of the poll tax.
The poll tax had a very clear intent, and that was to disenfranchise minority voters.
We have all kinds of tests implemented, such as how many bubbles are there in a bar of soap that excluded blacks from the polls.
This is not a modern day poll tax.
This is another modern day racial exclusionary tactic.
There are reasonable measures that states have put into place to have people show that they are who they present themselves, and when they come to the polls this - and not every district in Chicago.
Not everybody who's dead can vote in every state in the United States.
When I go to my polls, people know me but they've nevertheless require me to sign my name.
And they look to see how I previously signed my name so that I am Michael Meyers or I am who I say I am.
Now the real problem is when states may say there's only one form of ID we will accept, a government-issued ID.
That can have a disproportionate impact not just on minority voters, but on senior citizens and others who don't have government-issued ID, they don't have driver's licenses and things like that.
That becomes a problem.
That becomes a court test.
But this is not a racial barrier.
This is reasonable.
Well, let me jump in and go to you, Callie.
I interviewed Donna Brazile, who's one of our contributors on NEWS & NOTES, for a book that I wrote that was about basically the electoral process.
And she recounted a story in which her own sister was asked for multiple forms of ID, which is illegal.
It's not illegal to ask for ID but to ask for three forms of ID, that was clearly, in Donna Brazile's mind, an excessive effort and may well have been racially targeted.
Is the issue the voter ID law or is the issue the implementation?
I think it's the implementation.
I think that Michael is correct that it's proper to try to make certain that the person who's voting is the person who's voting.
But we've heard during the last election ways in which the use of this ID has frightened people.
I'm reminded that in Georgia there were large groups of Hispanic voters targeted.
And they said when you come to show your ID, we're going to find out whether or not your relatives are illegal and, you know, it's all this kind of stuff.
That's implementation.
That's allowing people to try to figure out a way to abuse it.
And that's always going to happen, of course.
But we have to know that this kind of scenario when minority folks have been asked for ID more often than not ends up being a scenario in which there is abuse.

You know, back in the day when you had to show various forms of ID to write a check, you know, there are many, many stories of black people being (unintelligible) well, that's not a good enough ID, or that's not valid or whatever, as a way of preventing them from being able to shop.
So we've seen the abuse of it, and it's a matter of just trying to figure out how to make certain that the implementation of the law is in place.
